Package battleship

Class Ocean

java.lang.Object
battleship.Ocean
public class Ocean
extends java.lang.Object
Represents an ocean with a fleet of ships, containing a 10x10 array of Ships. Name: SINA ALIPOUR-NAZARI PennID: 20359038 PennKey: snazari Statement: Completed in collaboration with Alexandros Khor and Mai N. Nguyen

  • Field Summary

    Fields
    Modifier and Type Field Description

    Number of times a shot hit a ship.
    private static int NUM_BATTLESHIPS
    Default number of ships in fleet per type.
    private static int NUM_CRUISERS  
    private static int NUM_DESTROYERS  
    private static int NUM_SUBMARINES  
    private Ship[][] ships
    Array of ships/empty sea used to determine ships location.
    private int shipsSunk
    Number of ships sunk (10 ships total).
    private int shotsFired
    Total number of shots fired.

    Ocean()

  • Field Details

    • NUM_BATTLESHIPS

      private static int NUM_BATTLESHIPS
      Default number of ships in fleet per type.

    • NUM_CRUISERS

      private static int NUM_CRUISERS

    • NUM_DESTROYERS

      private static int NUM_DESTROYERS

    • NUM_SUBMARINES

      private static int NUM_SUBMARINES

      private Ship[][] ships
      Array of ships/empty sea used to determine ships location.

    • shotsFired

      private int shotsFired
      Total number of shots fired.

      private int hitCount
      Number of times a shot hit a ship.

    • shipsSunk

      private int shipsSunk
      Number of ships sunk (10 ships total).

  • Constructor Details

    • Ocean

      public Ocean()
      Creates an "empty" ocean (and fills the ships array with EmptySea objects). Initializes any game variables (ex. shotsFired etc.).

  • Method Details

    • fillEmptyOcean

      private void fillEmptyOcean()
      Fills Ocean class with EmptySea objects in a 10x10 array.

    • placeAllShipsRandomly

      void placeAllShipsRandomly()
      Places all ten ships randomly on the (initially empty) ocean. Place larger ships before smaller ones. Utilizes the Random class.

    • isOccupied

      boolean isOccupied​(int row, int column)
      Returns true if the given location contains a ship, false if it does not.
      Parameters:
      row - coordinates in ocean array
      column - coordinates in ocean array
      Returns:
      boolean

    • shootAt

      boolean shootAt​(int row, int column)
      Returns true if the given location contains a "real" ship, still afloat and not an EmptySea object, false if it does not. Updates the number of shots fired and the number of hits. Note: Returns true if location a "real" ship even if shot multiple times. Once a ship has been "sunk", additional shots at its location should return false.
      Parameters:
      row - coordinates in ocean array
      column - coordinates in ocean array
      Returns:
      boolean

    • getShotsFired

      int getShotsFired()
      Returns the number of shots fired in the game.
      Returns:
      integer, shotsFired

    • getHitCount

      int getHitCount()
      Returns the number of hits recorded in the game. All hits are counted, not just the first time a given square is hit.
      Returns:
      integer, hitCount

    • getShipsSunk

      int getShipsSunk()
      Returns the number of ships sunk in the game.
      Returns:
      integer, shipsSunk

    • isGameOver

      boolean isGameOver()
      Returns true if all ships ahve been sunk, otherwise false.
      Returns:
      boolean true if game is over, else false.

    • getShipArray

      Ship[][] getShipArray()
      Gets the 10x10 array of Ships. Method is used in Ship class, to view contents in array and modify it in placeShipAt() method.
      Returns:
      Ships array object

    • print

      void print()
      Prints the Ocean. Row numbers are displayed along the left edge of the array. Column numbers are displaced along the top edge of the array. Numbers range from 0 to 9, not 1 to 10. Top left corner square is 0,0. 'x': Use 'x' to indicate a location that you have fired upon and hit a (real) ship. '-': Use '-' to indicate a location that you have fired upon and found nothing there. 's': Use 's' to indicate a location containing a sunken ship. '.': Use '.' to indicate a location that you have never fired upon.
